facts.text: Appellants were police constables at the time of the occurrence.
Appellants convicted by Special Judge Delhi under s.120B and s.224/109 IPC and s.5(2) Prevention of Corruption Act 1947.
Sentenced to 2 years RI under s.5(2) PCA 1947 and 9 months RI under each of ss.120B and 224/109 IPC, sentences to run concurrently.
Appeals to Punjab High Court Circuit Bench at Delhi dismissed on November 16, 1956.

Prosecution case: Appellants conspired at Delhi with Ram Saran Das (approver), M.P. Khare (undertrial prisoner), Nand Parkash Kapur and Murari between 6th and 16th November 1955 to bring about escape of M.P. Khare from lawful custody.
Appellants agreed to accept Rs.1,000 each and other pecuniary advantages as illegal gratification for rendering the escape.
In pursuance of conspiracy, appellants abetted escape of M.P. Khare and accepted illegal gratification from Nand Parkash Kapur.
M.P. Khare escaped from lawful custody, enabled by appellants who received money as illegal gratification.
District Magistrate of Delhi tendered pardon to approver Ram Saran Das under s.337 CrPC on 1-12-1955.
Prosecution witnesses Mela Ram (PW6) and Shiv Parshad (PW7) gave evidence; not accomplices.
No test identification parade of appellants held.
Single charge framed under ss.120B, 224/109 IPC and s.5(2) PCA instead of separate charges.
Objection to single charge raised before Special Judge but abandoned by appellants' advocate; public prosecutor urged separate charges but overruled at accused's request.

legal_issues.text: Whether pardon tendered to approver Ram Saran Das by District Magistrate under s.337 CrPC was without jurisdiction as case triable by Special Judge, rendering approver's evidence inadmissible.
Whether offence was under s.222 IPC (non-cognizable) not s.224 IPC, requiring sanction under s.196A CrPC for conspiracy charge under s.120B IPC.
Whether PW6 Mela Ram and PW7 Shiv Parshad were accomplices whose testimony could not corroborate approver.
Whether failure to hold test identification parade rendered identification evidence inadmissible or unreliable.
Whether single charge contravened mandatory provisions of s.233 CrPC.

petitioner_arguments.text: Pardon to Ram Saran Das by District Magistrate under s.337 CrPC without jurisdiction as offence triable exclusively by Special Judge under Criminal Law Amendment Act 1952; approver's evidence inadmissible.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.337 CrPC; Criminal Law Amendment Act 1952

petitioner_arguments.text: Offence of conspiracy to commit under s.224 IPC actually under s.222 IPC (non-cognizable); no sanction under s.196A CrPC for s.120B IPC conviction.
PW6 Mela Ram and PW7 Shiv Parshad were accomplices on their own showing; their testimony could not be considered to corroborate approver.
No test identification parade held for appellants.
Charge as framed contravened s.233 CrPC by not framing separate charges.

court_reasoning.text: PW6 and PW7 not accomplices; courts below entitled to believe them; no prior argument before High Court that they were accomplices.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Nothing in their evidence establishes them as accomplices.

court_reasoning.text: Failure to hold test identification parade does not make identification evidence inadmissible; weight is for courts of fact.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellants known to police witnesses; only some witnesses needed parade, but non-holding not fatal.

court_reasoning.text: Irregularity in single charge cured by s.537 CrPC; objection abandoned by appellants' advocate before Special Judge; no prejudice.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Accused urged charge as framed was correct; cannot raise now.

court_reasoning.text: Even if offence under s.222 not s.224 IPC, academic if conviction under s.5(2) PCA upheld; sanction issue not raised below, cannot investigate now.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Question of fact not urged at trial or High Court.

court_reasoning.text: District Magistrate had authority under s.337 CrPC to tender pardon as Special Judge deemed Court of Session under s.8(3) Criminal Law Amendment Act 1952; amendment to s.337 post-pardon irrelevant.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Special Judge for CrPC purposes is Court of Session; DM empowered concurrently with Special Judge.

holdings.text: Pardon valid; approver's evidence admissible as Special Judge deemed Court of Session under s.8(3) Criminal Law Amendment Act 1952, empowering DM under s.337 CrPC.
PW6 and PW7 not accomplices; their evidence reliable.
No TI parade failure not fatal to identification evidence.
Charge irregularity cured by s.537 CrPC; no prejudice to appellants.
Sanction issue academic and not raisable at this stage.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court rejected all five contentions raised by appellants, upheld validity of pardon, convictions and sentences by Special Judge and High Court; appeals by special leave dismissed.

key_quotes.text: "Under s.8(3) of the Criminal Law Amendment Act of 1952 it is expressly stated that for the purposes of the provisions of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898, the Court of Special Judge shall be deemed to be a Court of Session trying cases without a jury or without the aid of assessors."

key_quotes.significance: Basis for upholding District Magistrate's authority to tender pardon

key_quotes.text: "the irregularity committed, in this case, was cured by the provisions of s.537 of the Code."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Curing defect in framing single charge
